posts.name: Ben Miller
posts.cooked:
Hi there,

We’ve been having some problems passing the robotpy tests. The code we have written functions in both teleoperated and autonomous modes. When deploying we just override the “are you sure” commands and the robot works as intended but we cannot seem to pass these deployment tests.

the traceback looks like this:

Essentially, I am not sure where in our codebase we are reinitilizing the robot container that is leading to this error. I’ve crawled through our code looking for an instance outside of robot.py that we are initializing the robot container again and haven’t found one. Is there are reinitialization of robotInit that is called in test or disabled mode that I don’t know about?

our github is here . I’ve tried lots of things but am unsure where we are going astray here. This is pretty much the python kitbot code from FRC and andymark.

If you can help you’d have my thanks as testing new code is more challenging now as we cannot find other errors as the code isn’t passing as it stands.

link_counts.title: GitHub - FRC-Team-9056/FRC_Comp_2024: Code for the Kitbot in 2024

posts.name: Peter Hansen
posts.cooked:
I have a strong suspicion this is a spurious error, resulting perhaps from something in the test infrastructure or the rev library, which is causing the instance to be kept across multiple tests.  Perhaps the rev library uses a global internally that doesn’t get cleaned up properly between tests.

I went through the same thing yesterday for a while, before confirming (since I had very simple code that could not possibly have been making multiple instances) that it was not my fault, and then I just added --skip-tests when I deployed and lived with it for now.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
I’m not an expert in using frcpy, but i t looks as if commands2.TimedCommandRobot is scheduling a notifier that may prevent associated resources from being tidied up, perhaps including the default command that requires the drive subsystem.

The corresponding Java code stops the notifier when endCompetition is called.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

I’m not an expert in using frcpy, but i t looks as if commands2.TimedCommandRobot is scheduling a notifier that may prevent associated resources from being tidied up, perhaps including the default command that requires the drive subsystem.

Nope, all of the wpilib globals are cleaned up here: pyfrc/pyfrc/test_support/pytest_plugin.py at bc9ecadb8186e23f2a5240581d2c8d47e8e919c7 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub

As others noted, it is likely that something is holding the instance somewhere, but figuring out where exactly is challenging. The only realistic way to solve this issue permanently is via Run tests in subprocess instead of reloading robot code · Issue #230 · robotpy/pyfrc · GitHub , but nobody has done it yet.
